appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr: Mashonaland West Province is facing an unprecedented surge in malaria cases, with the current outbreak officially reported in February 2025, contributing to the national total of 36,423 cases and 85 deaths for the 15 weeks of 2025 (MoHCC, Malaria Highlights, 2025). The most affected districts are Hurungwe, Makonde, Zvimba, Mhondoro and Kariba, with 643 cases reported in the last 24 hours and a Case Fatality Rate of 0.36%. Mashonaland West Province specifically accounts for approximately 12.8% of the cases, placing it among the top four provinces affected by malaria, alongside Mashonaland Central, Manicaland, and Mashonaland East. Since January 2025, Mash West has recorded 11,790 cumulative cases and 42 confirmed deaths (MoHCC SitRep, April 2025). The cumulative malaria cases for weeks 1 to 15 increased by 107% from 17,539 cases in 2024 to 36,423 cases in 2025 (MoHCC, Malaria Highlights, 2025). Major risk factors include low risk perception and late health-seeking behaviour, resulting in patients presenting at the local health facility very late. As such, most patients are presenting at the health facility in severe conditions, leading to deaths. The 2023/24 La Nina season brought a lot of rainfall across the entire country, creating favourable conditions for mosquito breeding. Malaria is one of the top 5 killers of children under five in Zimbabwe, especially in rural and endemic provinces, including Mashonaland West. Malaria transmission in Zimbabwe is high during the rainy season, where approximately 67.5% of the population is at risk. Transmission in the country is usually from November to May, and the peak transmission period is from February to May of each year.
field_reports.description: The malaria outbreak has resulted in increased morbidity and mortality, with 85 confirmed deaths reported as of 26 April 2025. The surge in malaria cases has placed additional pressure on healthcare facilities, particularly in rural areas where resources are limited. Clinics and hospitals have faced increased patient loads, leading to potential shortages in medical supplies and staff fatigue. The focus on managing the malaria outbreak has diverted attention and resources from other essential health services, such as maternal and child health programs, immunizations, and management of chronic diseases. Other secondary effects include absenteeism from work among adults and from school among children, affecting their academic performance and long-term educational outcomes. The outbreak has also caused anxiety and stress among community members, particularly in areas with high infection rates. Fear of contracting the disease and concerns about the availability of treatment have impacted mental well-being. The province is also facing a cholera outbreak, which started on the 4th of November 2024 in Kariba district.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

results.name: ZWE: Election Preparedness
results.summary:
In line with the Zimbabwe Constitution, the country holds national harmonized elections every five years, also called general elections. Hence, the next elections will be held on the 23rd of August 2023 and will include the Presidential, Parliamentary and Local council elections. Following the constitution, If there is no outright winner in the presidential contest (winning with more than 50% votes), a run-off will is held six weeks later (october). Dubbed as “dry run” to this year’s contested election, the by-election tension, voting process and the extreme political polarization in the country may lead to situations of violence during the election period. Already, politically linked violent events have been reported successively since 2022. The most significant recent examples include some skirmishes reported in recent weeks which led malicious damage to property, livelihoods and infrastructure reported in Nyatsime, Chitungwiza on the outskirts of Harare.

Hence, multiple elements are indicating a possibility of violence in the impending 2023 elections.

This analysis highlighted by several analysis from experts, media National and international is premised on the following indicators:

a. The historical trend in Zimbabwe depicts an upsurge of violence around elections time. Inter and intra-political party skirmishes at recent political meetings and the 22 March 2022 By-election. In March 2022, the country held by-elections to fill vacant parliamentary and council seats. The run-up to these by-elections witnessed violence incidences and, in some cases, Red Cross volunteers assisted the victims.

b. There are verbal attacks and counter attacks in the media between the political parties with increased political activism in the country leading to a tense political environment.

c. Lack of political tolerance in some areas which has previously experienced disputed election results which in turn ignited violence.

d. Inadequate reconciliation efforts post 2008 violence and the deaths and injuries in the post 2018 election period which predisposes people towards a tendency of violence as revenge.

e. Possibility of an increase in migration towards the elections as people return to vote.

f. Emerging pressure groups which are not directly affiliated to political parties wield potential influence in political agitation.

g. Proliferation of social media (Facebook, Twitter & WhatsApp) as political mobilization tools may result in mass agitation and protests.

h. The economic challenges and hardships have heightened tension which may cause political agitation and sporadic incidences of public disobedience (riots and protests).

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

results.name: ZWE:Cholera Outbreak
results.summary:
The first cholera outbreak of 2023 started on 12 February 2023 in Chegutu town in Mashonaland West Province. As of 20th January 2024, Zimbabwe has recorded 19,477 suspected cholera cases , 71 laboratory confirmed deaths, 350 suspected cholera deaths & 2,252 laboratory confirmed cases. The crude mortality rate remains above 2.2% and raises concerns regarding case management and the quality of care. Due to the high rate of transmission, the disease is now affecting people across multiple geographical areas. To date, suspected and confirmed cases have been reported in 45 out of 62 districts and in all 10 provinces of the country. The outbreak has now spread to more than the 17 traditional cholera hotspot districts, putting at risk over 10 million people, including more than five million children. Transmission routes from Buhera and Mutare have contributed to the spread of the outbreak in urban populations as well as the spike in cases in Harare and Chitungwiza.

 

The capacity of the Ministry of Health and Child Care has been stretched due to the high number of admissions, lack of human resources to manage the caseload, and lack of cholera supplies, including disinfection liquids, to stop the transmission. There is a disrupted community health care system where primary health care - which is responsible for ensuring that community members adhere to water, sanitation, and hygiene practices - is overwhelmed. Active case findings and surveillance have been challenged, compounded by inadequate logistical supplies. There is a need to mobilise and train more volunteers to support task shifting from medical personnel to volunteers, as well as support in increasing the awareness of risks and treatment.

 

In June 2023, the Zimbabwe Red Cross Society (ZRCS) requested CHF 464,595 from the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) Disaster Response Emergency Fund to fight the cholera outbreak, which showed a positive response in the targeted districts. However, the outbreak has spread to new districts, prompting the ZMRC to move the current situation in its scenario planning to a “worst-case scenario”. The launch of this Emergency Appeal for CHF 3 million is to enable the ZRCS to further scale-up their response, with 550,455 people targeted across the most affected and vulnerable districts and their communities.

field_reports.affected_pop_centres: Chiredzi Rural, Chipinge, Mudzi, Binga, Mangwe, Muzarabani, Gokwe, Buhera and Zaka Districts
field_reports.description:
The 2021-22 season can generally be described as poor. It was characterized by a fall start to the season followed by erratic rainfall punctuated by very long dry spells. The resulted in the area planted to maize decreasing by 1% from 1 920 541ha in the 2020/21 season to 1 903 669 Ha in 2021/22 (2021-22 First Round Crop Assessment Report)
This is likely to result in below-average harvests by April or May which will only result in temporary improvements to food security outcomes. As reported by Fews Net, in typical surplus-producing areas, Minimal (IPC Phase 1) outcomes will be limited, while Stressed (IPC Phase 2) outcomes will be widespread. Typical deficit-producing areas are expected to experience mainly Stressed (IPC Phase 2) as households will only be able to meet their minimal food needs but not their non-food needs. These areas, mainly parts of Manicaland, Masvingo, Midlands, and the Matabeleland Provinces are expected to deteriorate to Crisis (IPC Phase 3) by July, prompting an early start to the next lean season.
field_reports.summary: ZWE: Food Insecurity - 2022-06 - Zimbabwe Agricultural Drought

results.name: ZWE: Drought Protocol
results.summary:
The IFRC Disaster Response Emergency Fund (DREF) has approved a total of CHF 549,318.00 for the Zimbabwe Red Cross Society’s Early Action Protocol on droughts. The approved amount consists of an allocation of CHF 182,440 for readiness and CHF 366,878 allocated to implement early actions once the defined triggers are met. Allocations are made from the Anticipatory Pillar of the DREF, under the DREF appeal code MDR00001. Unearmarked contributions to the DREF are encouraged to guarantee enough funding is available for the Early Action Protocols being developed. The Drought Early Action Protocol (EAP) for the Zimbabwe Red Cross Society (ZRCS) is a tool to guide the timely and effective implementation of early actions based on forecast and observational data, which predict meteorological hazards with a high likelihood of humanitarian impact. Drought (Meteorological and Agricultural) is the most common and high-impact natural hazard occurring in Zimbabwe, both in terms of frequency of occurrence and the number of people affected, with droughts accounting for 7 out of the 10 top major natural hazards since recorded 1990. Due to increasing climatic uncertainty, and reduced coping capacity, the risk of drought has spread to all areas of the country and is affecting a broader range of people, in both urban and rural areas. Furthermore, the impacts of this hazard are predicted to increase, with the World Bank Group Climate Change Knowledge Portal, predicting the annual likelihood of Zimbabwe encountering severe drought to increase by 21% in 2040 to 2059 and by 47% in 2080 to 2099 compared to the baseline period of 1986 to 2005 scenario. 

At a national scale, droughts often result in crop failure, loss of livestock and wildlife, and power outages. The country’s worst drought occurred in 1991/2, directly affecting 5 million people and resulting in serious food insecurity and water shortages which had a ripple effect on the Southern African region compromising food security in countries that were reliant on Zimbabwe’s food exports. Repeated drought exposure has entrenched vulnerabilities and reduced the coping capacities of small-scale farmers, leaving an increasing number of people who are affected by the impacts of drought. This EAP has been developed through extensive consultation with key informants, at the community, district, and National levels, and has been supported by technical guidance from the 510 Data initiative and the Red Cross Red Crescent Climate Centre. The monitoring of the hazard and the implementation of the Early Actions will be led by the ZRCS, guided by relevant Government of Zimbabwe (GoZ) departments, including the Agricultural Extension Department, the Veterinary Department, and the Meteorological Services Department. This EAP has also been developed with close reference to the Government of Zimbabwe National Drought Plan and aligns the identified roles of the Zimbabwe Red Cross and other stakeholders. Technical and financial support for the development of this EAP has been provided by the Danish Red Cross and Finnish Red Cross Societies.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
Zimbabwe measles cases have doubled from 1036 to 2056 in four days(as of the 15th of August 2022). From the last update, on the 7th of June 2022, a total of 348 cases and 34 deaths had  been confirmed since April 2022 in Mutasa District Manicaland province (the most affected province)
However as of the 15th of August 2022, the disease had spread to all the 10 provinces with 2056 confirmed cases and 157 deaths. Manicaland remains the most affected with 1270 cases and 122 deaths, Harare 121 cases and 0 deaths, Midlands 83 cases and 16 deaths, Masvingo 116 cases and 3 deaths, Mashonaland East 115 and 16 deaths, Mashonaland Central 87 cases and 0 deaths, Mashonaland West 130 cases and 0 deaths, Matebeleland North 85 cases and 0 deaths, Matebeleland South 23 cases and 0 deaths, Bulawayo 12 cases and 0 deaths. The National vaccination programme which was targeting under 5 children has been scaled up to target the 6 months to 15 year old age group as these are the most affected.
field_reports.description:
ZIMBABWE has been hit by a deadly national measles outbreak which has killed 157 children from 2056 cases reported in all the provinces between April and August 2022. The disruption of vaccination activities by the COVID-19 pandemic has increased the risk of the disease which initially affected a single district in June but has now spread across all the 10 provinces of the country. Cases continue to rise and mass vaccination initiatives need scaling up to enhance coverage and reach. Most of the identified cases have not been vaccinated against measles. Risk for infection among children under 15 years remains high especially among some anti-vaccination apostolic sects. Consequently, it has led to a surge in deaths and other related complications. Measles can be a serious disease, with 30% of reported cases experiencing one or more complications. Most complications occur mostly in children and pregnant women. Measles during pregnancy increases the risk of premature labor, miscarriage, and low-birth-weight infants. Measles is more severe in malnourished children, particularly those with vitamin A deficiency. Also if not treated early, the child may develop the following: = Severe cough = Pneumonia = Blindness = Deafness = Malnutrition
In addition, Mozambique & Malawi have reported confirmed polio cases posing a risk of importation in Zimbabwe and the region due to high cross border movement between Zimbabwe and Mozambique, Malawi thus the health ministry remains on high alert with active screening going on across the country. The MOHCC has requested support from the Red Cross to urgently support the response across the country.

field_reports.epi_notes_since_last_fr:
As of 29th May, total of 348 cases have so far been identified since the first rumours surfaced on 10 April 2022 in Mutasa District. 40 are vaccinated, 274 are not vaccinated and 30 have unknown
vaccination status. 34 deaths have so far been recorded with a fatality rate of 12.6%.
Of the 34 deaths, 25 were unvaccinated and 9 vaccination status is unknown. Zindi clinic has reported 229 cases so far contributing 66.1%. Second highest facility is Gatsi with 20 cases. 339 cases are from Mutasa district and 9 from Mutare city.
The most affected age group is the 1 to 4 years age group (127) as detailed below:
• 5 to 9 years (119)
• 10 to 14 years (61)
• Under ones (29)
• Above 15 years (9)
• Age unknown (3)
field_reports.description:
ZIMBABWE has been hit by a deadly measles outbreak which has killed 34 children from 348 cases reported in Mutasa District, Manicaland province between January and May 2022. The disruption of vaccination activities by COVID-19 has increased the risk and if not managed children below 5 years remain at high risk and could see a surge in deaths. Measles can be a serious disease, with 30% of reported cases experiencing one or more complications. Most complications occur mostly in children and pregnant women. Measles during pregnancy increases the risk of premature labor, miscarriage, and low-birth-weight infants. Measles is more severe in malnourished children, particularly those with vitamin A deficiency. Also if not treated early, the child may develop the following: = Severe cough = Pneumonia = Blindness = Deafness = Malnutrition
In addition, Mozambique & Malawi have recently reported confirmed polio cases posing a risk of importation in Zimbabwe and the region due to high cross border movement between Zimbabwe and Mozambique, Malawi.

In order to control this outbreak, the health ministry has started a mass vaccination campaign in Mutasa District, Manicaland province targeting the 6 months to 5 years age group regardless of their vaccination status.
field_reports.summary: ZWE: Epidemic - 2022-06 - Measles outbreak and polio risk in Zimbabwe

results.name: ZWE: Epidemic - 2022-06 - Measles outbreak and polio risk in Zimbabwe
results.summary: From early April 2022, Zimbabwe was affected by a national measles outbreak, that killed more than 750 childrenwithin the outbreak’s first 6 months to the 2nd of October 2022. This outbreak saw humanitarian organizations like UNICEF, Red Cross and the WHO activating an emergency response strategy to provide support and resources to the Government of Zimbabwe (GoZ). The first case was recorded in Manicaland province on the 10 April 2022 in Mutasa district and by the 31st of August, 639 children had succumbed to the virus accumulating to 750 deaths by early October. In response, the Government of Zimbabwe has rolled out a nationwide emergency immunization programme targeting 95% of all children from 6-59 months and in some instances up to 15 years in an attempt to attain herd immunity. Nationally, there are reports that cumulatively around 85 % of all children under the age of five are fullyvaccinated against measles by the 2nd of October 2022. Currently the GoZ’s focus is ramping up efforts to immunizethe remaining eligible populations prioritizing Manicaland Province. According to the Midlands Province MOHCC, 65%of all children under the age of five are fully vaccinated against measles by the 20 October 2022.Vaccinations have been ongoing at all static facilities and outreach teams were visiting hard-to-reach areas and children in the 6-59 months category are being vaccinated irrespective of their vaccination status. At least 85% of the children have been vaccinated in Manicaland Province and of the 7 413 children affected by measles, 5 600 have recovered, representing 76% recovery. Countrywide immunization will continue until all the areas are covered in as much as it continues until it reaches the national 95% vaccination target.

field_reports.description: Over the month of November there have been sporadic humanitarian incidences resulting from hydro meteorological hazards namely Windstorms, hailstorms and lightning. These incidences have occurred at different dates and different locations across Zimbabwe.  The incidences left a trail of destruction as peoples homesteads have been destroyed (rooftops blown away and structures collapsing), key infrastructure such as schools and health facilities have also been affected. Critical infrastructure such as roads, electricity poles and bridges were also destroyed. A number of people have been displaced thus requiring temporary shelter, whilst a significant number also requires  Health and WASH support.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Zimbabwe, Malawi and Zambia

field_reports.description:
Tropical cyclone Eloise made landfall in Mozambique early on Saturday, hitting the coastal city of Beira with huge gusts of wind and heavy rains. Eloise made landfall around 2:30 a.m. in the morning with wind speeds of 160 kilometres per hour (kph) (99 miles per hour). The World Meteorological Organisation in a Twitter post said the cyclone had weakened to a tropical storm, and will bring heavy rains to parts of Zimbabwe, South Africa, Botswana
After its landfall in Mozambique, the Eloise weather system is expected to bring heavy rains to southern Zimbabwe, northern South Africa and far eastern Botswana, according to Meteo France. In Zimbabwe, heavy rains are forecast in the southern parts of Manicaland Province as early as the evening of 22 January, with heavy rains over Manicaland Province, the southern parts of Masvingo Province expected by 23 January, potentially spreading into southern Matabeleland South Province on 24 January, according to the Department of Civil Protection (DCP) and Meteorological Services Department.
This is likely to cause extensive damage to roads infrastructure resulting in limited road access to the most affected people, though the extent of the need remains uncertain. Preparatory rescue and response efforts are underway, being coordinated through the Department of Civil Protection. The cyclone is also expected to hit areas that were destroyed by Cyclone Idai in 2019 and some people are still leaving in temporal structures as such DCP has initiated evacuation of these people to higher grounds (safe spaces). 
To date a total number of 265 persons (103 households) in Manicaland have be evacuated to four (4) evacuation centres. In Chipinge and other surrounding wards near Save downstream, people are being encouraged to go to designated evacuation centres within their wards because of fear of backflow of Save river. Additionally, Covid-19 remains a threat with 4 people having been tested positive in one of the evacuations in Manicaland. Masvingo Province which lies along the path of the cyclone is also anticipating floods from the overflowing of Tokwe Mkosi Dam to that effect DCP is planning to move 250 households in Chivi District and 50 Households in Masvingo District to safer evacuation centres. In Mashonaland East Province there has been reports of damages to approximately 15 houses and road infrastructure in Chikomba District. They have also identified 6 evacuation centres, and no one has been taken to the centres yet and these are at schools in safer zones according to Civil Protection Unit (CPU). In Matebeleland South, there has being continuous rains across the province with high risk of flooding as most places were already saturated from the previous rains that have been ongoing.

Information gathered from the Zimbabwe Red Cross Society field teams and Government sources indicate that the storm surge emanating from Tropical Storm Chalene has so far caused wide spread damage in Mutare Urban, Mutare Rural and Chipinge Districts. Some urban dwellings in Mutare have seen their houses and concrete walls being destructed. In Chipinge District crop fields have been submerged and excessive winds have uprooted trees resulting in roads being blocked. Daily updates from the Zimbabwe Meteorological Department indicate that the Tropical depression  has since weakened; however there will be continuous monitoring of specific areas to assess rainfall and downstream effect.  Light rains, windy and overcast conditions are projected to continue in the next 24 hours.

appeals.sector: Country cluster for Mozambique and Angola

field_reports.description: The Meteorological Service Department of Zimbabwe has issued an alert of a tropical storm which has been observed in the Indian ocean north west of Mauritius. The storm is strengthening and drifting west wards toward Madagascar. The likely path has favorable atmospheric conditions that will allow the storm to strengthen and as the storm strengthens, it will continue to move westwards. By the 26th of December 2020 it will have developed into a severe storm. Madagascar is expected  start to experience heavy rainfall, very strong gusty winds end of the week. Between first and second of January 2021 the system is expected to arrive in the Mozambique channel. It may emerge from the Mozambique channel with regained strength to reach the eastern parts of Zimbabwe with disastrous consequences. Adverse weather conditions such as heavy rain storm, strong wind gusts and floods are expected to cause heavy humanitarian consequences exacerbated by the already existing vulnerabilities given that the  locations, still smarting from the  TC Idai, were yet to fully recover and thus have limited capacity to limit the impact of the potential events. The government has since activated response mechanism in the country to trigger preparedness activities. Extremely exposed are some families still living in tents established post Idai, these are being prioritized for evacuation by the government.  Shelter weakened already by TC idai will likely succumb and induce shelter and sanitation humanitarian needs. other sectors such as health, food, water, education will potentially be impacted.

Since the 15th of November 2020, Zimbabwe has been  experiencing rainfall, in most cases coupled with isolated storms with adversely damaging variables  such as lightning, hail, strong winds and flash flooding.  These adverse storm conditions have affected Masvingo, Manicaland, Matebeleland South as a well as Matebeleland North provinces.  True to the forecast issued by the Meteorological Services Department these damaging rains started to persist and become widespread  from the 28th of November and to date the damaging downpours have now recorded damages in Gokwe North in Midlands province. The storm has resulted in some infrastructural damage affecting roads and destroying houses leading to urgent need for humanitarian support for WASH, Shelter, NFIs, PSS and food.  Assessments are currently ongoing to ascertain the magnitude of the damage although in some places efforts are being hampered by the rains received. 
In Masvingo Province, Masvingo city was affected and Mwenezi District were the storm was accompanied with strong winds which uprooted trees and drenched property inside most homes on the 25th of November 2020. Some were left with no food as the roofs were blown away exposing the food items to heavy rains and others were left injured while trying to escape. In some cases, households were left with nothing as their houses were destroyed to the ground and they are currently being assisted by neighbors. These emergencies are expected to escalate in the next weeks as torrential rains have been forecasted to persist in the next 8 days, usually this induces flooding and collapse of houses and toilets as the ground gets saturated.
field_reports.summary: Devastating Storms in multiple provinces of Zimbabwe

results.name: Devastating Storms in multiple provinces of Zimbabwe
